The "Child Care Infrastructure Act of 1996" allows for a credit for employer expenses for child care assistance under the new section 45D of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Child Care Infrastructure Act of 1996" introduces a credit for employer-provided child care expenses under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code. The credit covers 50% of qualified child care expenditures, not exceeding $150,000 per year. Qualified expenses include property acquisition, construction, rehabilitation, or expansion for child care purposes. The "Child Care Infrastructure Act of 1996" allows a credit for employer-provided child care expenses under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code. The credit covers 50% of qualified child care expenditures, capped at $150,000 per year. Qualified expenses include property acquisition, construction, rehabilitation, or expansion for child care facilities. The tax credit applies to property used for a qualified child care facility, eligible for depreciation, and not part of the taxpayer's or employee's principal residence. The tax credit applies to operating costs of a qualified child care facility, including employee training, scholarship programs, and increased compensation for trained employees. The tax credit covers costs for employee training, scholarship programs, increased compensation for trained employees, and services provided by a qualified child care facility. A qualified child care facility is a facility that provides dependent care assistance and meets all applicable state laws and regulations. A qualified child care facility is defined as a facility that primarily offers dependent care assistance and complies with all relevant state or local laws and regulations, including licensing requirements. A qualified child care facility must comply with state and local laws, including licensing requirements, except for facilities that are the operator's principal residence. The facility must also be open to the taxpayer's employees for enrollment. A qualified child care facility must comply with state and local laws, including licensing requirements. Enrollment in the facility must be open to employees of the taxpayer, and the facility cannot be the taxpayer's principal trade or business unless at least 30 percent of the enrollees are dependents of the taxpayer's employees. The qualified child care facility must comply with state and local laws, including licensing requirements. Enrollment must be open to employees of the taxpayer, and the facility cannot be the taxpayer's main business unless 30% of enrollees are employees' dependents. Discrimination in favor of highly compensated employees is not allowed. The tax code prohibits discrimination in favor of highly compensated employees regarding the use of qualified child care facilities. If there is a recapture event with respect to a facility, the taxpayer's tax for that year will increase by a certain percentage. If a recapture event occurs with a qualified child care facility, the taxpayer's tax will increase by a certain percentage based on the decrease in credits allowed for prior years. If a recapture event happens at a qualified child care facility, the taxpayer's tax will increase based on the decrease in credits allowed for prior years. The applicable recapture percentage is determined from a specific table. The recapture percentage for different years is as follows:
Years 1-3: 100%
Year 4: 85%
Year 5: 70%
Year 6: 55%
Year 7: 40%
Year 8: 25% The recapture percentage decreases over the years as follows: Year 4 - 85%, Year 5 - 70%, Year 6 - 55%, Year 7 - 40%, Year 8 - 25%, Years 9 and 10 - 10%, Years 11 and thereafter - 0%. The recapture event is defined as the cessation of operation or change in ownership of a qualified child care facility. Year 1 begins when the facility is placed in service by the taxpayer. The recapture event, as defined, includes the cessation of operation or change in ownership of a qualified child care facility. The disposition of a taxpayer's interest in a qualified child care facility triggers recapture liability unless the new owner agrees in writing to assume it. The disposition of a taxpayer's interest in a qualified child care facility triggers recapture liability unless the new owner agrees in writing to assume it. If the person acquiring the facility agrees to assume the recapture liability, they will be treated as the taxpayer for assessing any liabilities. The disposition of an interest in a qualified child care facility triggers recapture liability. The new owner can assume this liability and will be treated as the taxpayer for assessing any liabilities. The tax liability for credits used to reduce tax liability under this section will be increased for the taxable year. Unused credits will adjust carryforwards and carrybacks under section 39. The tax liability for credits used to reduce tax liability will be increased for the taxable year. Unused credits will adjust carryforwards and carrybacks under section 39. Any increase in tax under this subsection will not be considered a tax imposed by this chapter for determining the amount of any credit under subpart A, B, or D of this part. The tax liability for credits used to reduce tax liability will be appropriately adjusted. Any increase in tax under this subsection shall not affect the amount of any credit under subpart A, B, or D of this part. The increase in tax will not apply in case of a casualty loss to a qualified child care facility. The increase in tax under this subsection does not apply to a cessation of operation of a qualified child care facility due to a casualty loss, if the loss is restored within a reasonable period. Aggregation rules apply to all persons treated as a single employer for tax purposes. The tax credit for reconstruction or replacement must occur within a set timeframe. Special rules apply, such as treating related employers as a single taxpayer and allocating the credit among partners in partnerships. The tax credit for reconstruction or replacement must occur within a set timeframe. Related employers shall be treated as a single taxpayer, and the credit shall be allocated among partners in partnerships. Regulations will apply to ensure no double benefit. The credit for reconstruction or replacement must occur within a specified timeframe and will be allocated among partners in partnerships according to regulations. No double benefit will be allowed, with the basis of the property reduced by the amount of the credit determined. The basis of property is reduced by the credit amount determined, and if there is a recapture amount, the basis of the property will be increased by that amount. The basis of property is increased by the recapture amount, which is any increase in tax determined under subsection (d). No other deductions or credits are allowed with respect to the credit amount determined under this provision. The section provides for an increase in tax determined under subsection (d) and disallows any other deductions or credits related to the credit amount. It is specified that this section will not apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1999. Conforming amendments are made to Section 38(b) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The section disallows deductions or credits related to the credit amount and will not apply after December 31, 1999. Conforming amendments are made to Section 38(b) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The text amends the Internal Revenue Code by adding a new paragraph related to the employer-provided child care credit under section 45D. It also includes a new item in the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1996.
